title: Yabba dabba doo! There's still time to meet 'The Flintstones' roadside attraction
text:
Bedrock City isn’t bound for rubble just yet.

The Flintstones’ hometown, a popular stop on the way to the Grand Canyon, will remain open indefinitely while it slowly takes wing as Raptor Ranch in Arizona, reports the Arizona Republic, which is part of the USA TODAY Network.

Owner Troy Morris, who took over the prehistoric park in January, said visitors are welcome to stroll the grounds as construction continues. At this point, renovations aren’t obstructing access to Bedrock City.

“Until work gets in the way, there’s no reason to shut it down,” Morris said. The park had been slated to close at the end of summer, but people are still stopping by in surprising numbers.

Though Bedrock signs along the highway have been removed, tourists continue to stop by the kitschy gem. Morris estimated that more than 100 people stop each day to rock some quality time with the modern Stone Age family.

A fond farewell to Fred

Even more pull over for a few photos of the treasured roadside attraction based on "The Flintstones," a popular 1960s animated show featuring Fred Flintstone and best friend Barney Rubble.

Bedrock City had long been taken for granite before its impending closure was announced. That seemed to draw people out of the woodwork, and Morris said the vast majority of visitors are there for one last glimpse before Bedrock goes the way of the dinosaurs.

He discovered that many had been children when they first visited, and now were bringing their own kids to see what passed for road-trip entertainment before the invention of mobile devices and video games.

Visit with Fred Flintstone in Bedrock City. (Photo: Richard Maack)

“There are a lot of memories here for a lot of people,” Morris said. “We're happy to keep it open for as long as we can."

Work is nearly complete on the gift shop, which remains open (Bedrock-branded merchandise, however, is long extinct). Much of the focus now is on the restaurant as well as infrastructure, Morris said.

Bedrock City occupies a rich vein of Arizona history, one that runs back to the 1970s when contractor Francis Speckels was hired to build a companion park to the original Bedrock in Custer, S.D., whose pastel-hued structures from another eon lured travelers on their way to Mount Rushmore.

A similar strategy was employed for the western Bedrock City, which rose along a popular highway leading to the Grand Canyon.

The park was both a business and home for the Speckels family (Francis, his wife Linda and their five daughters). Francis died more than 20 years ago, and Linda ran Bedrock until selling it late last year.

When Morris opens Raptor Ranch — he hopes it will by the spring — many Bedrock remnants will remain, including characters, a few buildings and the park's longtime centerpiece, the brontosaurus slide. They’ll comprise a children’s playground.

Raptor Ranch will feature exhibits and demonstrations featuring falcons. Morris, a raptor breeder, said the birds will come from his collection.

Bedrock City

What: Park featuring buildings and characters from the 1960s cartoon "The Flintstones."

Where: On State Route 64, a quarter-mile north of U.S. 180, Valle, Arizona.

When: 9 a.m.-5 p.m. daily.

Admission: $5.

Camping: $25 per night for campsite, $40 for RV hookup.
